≤η⁢Bφ⁢A⁢‖θ¯K−θ¯K′‖absent𝜂subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴normsubscript¯𝜃𝐾superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝐾′\displaystyle\leq\eta B_{\varphi}A\left\|{\bar{\theta}_{K}-\bar{\theta}_{K}^{% \prime}}\right\|≤ italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∥ over¯ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ (Assumption 1)
≤η⁢Bφ⁢A⁢∑k=1K‖θk−θk′‖absent𝜂subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾normsubscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\displaystyle\leq\eta B_{\varphi}A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{\theta_{k}-\theta_{k}^% {\prime}}\right\|≤ italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ (Triangle inequality)
≤K⁢η⁢Bφ⁢A⁢maxk∈[K]⁡‖θk−θk′‖.absent𝐾𝜂subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾normsubscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\displaystyle\leq K\eta B_{\varphi}A\max_{k\in\left[K\right]}\left\|{\theta_{k% }-\theta_{k}^{\prime}}\right\|\,.≤ italic_K italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ .

Therefore, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-covering number for ΠlinsubscriptΠlin\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to the norm ∥⋅∥1\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒩ϵ(Πlin,∥⋅∥1)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is upper-bounded by the ϵK⁢η⁢Bφ⁢Aitalic-ϵ𝐾𝜂subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta B_{\varphi}A}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG-covering number of the Euclidean ball 𝔅⁢(Bθ)𝔅subscript𝐵𝜃\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with respect to the norm ∥⋅∥\left\|{\cdot}\right\|∥ ⋅ ∥, and

𝒩ϵ(Πlin,∥⋅∥1)\displaystyle\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢Bφ⁢A(𝔅(Bθ),∥⋅∥)\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta B_{\varphi}A}}\left(% \mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right),\left\|{\cdot}\right\|\right)≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ )
≤(1+2⁢K⁢η⁢Bθ⁢Bφ⁢Aϵ)d,absentsuperscript12𝐾𝜂subscript𝐵𝜃subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴italic-ϵ𝑑\displaystyle\leq\left(1+\frac{2K\eta B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\epsilon}\right)% ^{d}\,,≤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 italic_K italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where we used Lemma 12 in the last inequality. For the second part of the lemma, let us consider Q,Q′∈𝒬lin𝑄superscript𝑄′subscript𝒬linQ,Q^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}italic_Q , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By definition of 𝒬linsubscript𝒬lin\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there exists θ,θ′∈𝔅⁢(Bθ)𝜃superscript𝜃′𝔅subscript𝐵𝜃\theta,\theta^{\prime}\in\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right)italic_θ , italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that for any state-action pair (x,a)𝑥𝑎\left(x,a\right)( italic_x , italic_a ), Q⁢(x,a)=⟨φ⁢(x,a),θ⟩𝑄𝑥𝑎𝜑𝑥𝑎𝜃Q\left(x,a\right)=\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta\right\rangleitalic_Q ( italic_x , italic_a ) = ⟨ italic_φ ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_θ ⟩ and Q′⁢(x,a)=⟨φ⁢(x,a),θ′⟩superscript𝑄′𝑥𝑎𝜑𝑥𝑎superscript𝜃′Q^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)=\left\langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta^{\prime}\right\rangleitalic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) = ⟨ italic_φ ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩. Then,

maxx,a∈𝒳×𝒜⁡|Q⁢(x,a)−Q′⁢(x,a)|=maxx,a∈𝒳×𝒜⁡|⟨φ⁢(x,a),θ−θ′⟩|≤Bφ⁢‖θ−θ′‖.subscript𝑥𝑎𝒳𝒜𝑄𝑥𝑎superscript𝑄′𝑥𝑎subscript𝑥𝑎𝒳𝒜𝜑𝑥𝑎𝜃superscript𝜃′subscript𝐵𝜑norm𝜃superscript𝜃′\max_{x,a\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}\left|{Q\left(x,a\right)-Q^{\prime}% \left(x,a\right)}\right|=\max_{x,a\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}}\left|{\left% \langle\varphi\left(x,a\right),\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right\rangle}\right|\leq B% _{\varphi}\left\|{\theta-\theta^{\prime}}\right\|\,.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_a ∈ caligraphic_X × caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q ( italic_x , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) | = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_a ∈ caligraphic_X × caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ⟨ italic_φ ( italic_x , italic_a ) , italic_θ - italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ | ≤ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_θ - italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ .

Therefore, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-covering number of 𝒬linsubscript𝒬lin\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒩ϵ(𝒬lin,∥⋅∥∞)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_% {\infty}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is upper-bounded by the ϵ/Bφitalic-ϵsubscript𝐵𝜑\epsilon/B_{\varphi}italic_ϵ / italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-covering number of the d𝑑ditalic_d-dimensional ball with radius Bθsubscript𝐵𝜃B_{\theta}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒩ϵ/Bφ(𝔅(Bθ),∥⋅∥)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/B_{\varphi}}\left(\mathfrak{B}\left(B_{\theta}\right),% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ ). We have

𝒩ϵ(𝒬lin,∥⋅∥∞)≤𝒩ϵ/Bφ(𝔅(Bθ),∥⋅∥)≤(1+2⁢Bθ⁢Bφϵ)d.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_% {\infty}\right)\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/B_{\varphi}}\left(\mathfrak{B}\left(B% _{\theta}\right),\left\|{\cdot}\right\|\right)\leq\left(1+\frac{2B_{\theta}B_{% \varphi}}{\epsilon}\right)^{d}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( fraktur_B ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ ) ≤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Finally, the proof is concluded by noting that

𝒩ϵ(𝒬lin×Πlin,∥⋅∥∞,1)≤𝒩ϵ/2(Πlin,∥⋅∥1)𝒩ϵ/2(𝒬lin,∥⋅∥∞).\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}\times\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}}% ,\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\Pi% _{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left% (\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

∎

Finally, the following result proves the concentration of the estimators used in Algorithm 1.

See 3

Proof.

By Lemma 5, it holds that for all k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ]

Δ⁢(πk)Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\displaystyle\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤infϵ:ϵ>0{4⁢ϵ1−γ+2⁢2log(2𝒩ϵ(𝒬lin×Πlin,∥⋅∥∞,1)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE}\displaystyle\leq\inf_{\epsilon:\epsilon>0}\left\{\frac{4\epsilon}{1-\gamma}+2% \sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}% \times\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right% )}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\right\}≤ roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ : italic_ϵ > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG 4 italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG }
≤1K+2⁢2log(2𝒩(1−γ)/4⁢K(𝒬lin×Πlin,∥⋅∥∞,1)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{K}+2\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\left(1-% \gamma\right)/4K}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{\mathrm{lin}}\times\Pi_{\mathrm{lin}},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^% {2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_γ ) / 4 italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG
≤1K+2⁢2(1−γ)2⁢τE⁢log⁡(2δ⁢(1+16⁢K2⁢η⁢Bθ⁢Bφ⁢A1−γ)2⁢d)absent1𝐾22superscript1𝛾2subscript𝜏E2𝛿superscript116superscript𝐾2𝜂subscript𝐵𝜃subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴1𝛾2𝑑\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{K}+2\sqrt{\frac{2}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{2}{\delta}\left(1+\frac{16K^{2}% \eta B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{1-\gamma}\right)^{2d}\right)}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ( 1 + divide start_ARG 16 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG
≤1K+4⁢d(1−γ)2⁢τE⁢log⁡(2+32⁢K2⁢η⁢Bθ⁢Bφ⁢A(1−γ)⁢δ),absent1𝐾4𝑑superscript1𝛾2subscript𝜏E232superscript𝐾2𝜂subscript𝐵𝜃subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴1𝛾𝛿\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{K}+4\sqrt{\frac{d}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{2+32K^{2}\eta B_{\theta}B_{% \varphi}A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)\delta}\right)}\,,≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 4 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 + 32 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG ,

where the third inequality follows from Lemma 6. ∎

B.5 Proof of Theorem 1 (sample complexity guarantee for linear Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs)

See 1

Proof.

By Proposition 1, we have

𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]≤1K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[ℒ⁢(πk;Qk)]+2K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[Δ⁢(πk)].𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜌subscript𝜋Esuperscript𝜌superscript𝜋out1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑄𝑘2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(% \pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta% \left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\,.blackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] .

Using Lemma 2 with a learning rate of η=(1−γ)⁢2⁢log⁡AK𝜂1𝛾2𝐴𝐾\eta=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sqrt{\frac{2\log A}{K}}italic_η = ( 1 - italic_γ ) square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG and dividing by K𝐾Kitalic_K, we obtain that

1K⁢∑k=1Kℒ⁢(πk;Qk)≤2⁢log⁡A(1−γ)2⁢K.1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾ℒsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑄𝑘2𝐴superscript1𝛾2𝐾\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\leq\sqrt{\frac{% 2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}K}}\,.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_ARG end_ARG .

Therefore, setting K=2⁢log⁡A(1−γ)2⁢ε2𝐾2𝐴superscript1𝛾2superscript𝜀2K=\frac{2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}italic_K = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG guarantees 1K⁢∑k=1Kℒ⁢(πk;Qk)≤ε1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾ℒsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑄𝑘𝜀\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\leq\varepsilondivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_ε. Then, using the high-probability bound in Lemma 3 and the fact that 1K⁢∑k=1KΔ⁢(πk)1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a random random variable bounded by 2⁢(1−γ)−12superscript1𝛾12\left(1-\gamma\right)^{-1}2 ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT almost surely, we obtain the following expectation bound which holds for all δ>0𝛿0\delta>0italic_δ > 0,

1K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[Δ⁢(πk)]1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\displaystyle\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}% \right)\right]divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ≤1K+C⁢d(1−γ)2⁢τE⁢log⁡(Bθ⁢Bφ⁢A(1−γ)⁢δ⁢ε)+2⁢δ1−γ,absent1𝐾𝐶𝑑superscript1𝛾2subscript𝜏Esubscript𝐵𝜃subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴1𝛾𝛿𝜀2𝛿1𝛾\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{K}+C\sqrt{\frac{d}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)\delta\varepsilon}\right)}+\frac{2\delta}{1-\gamma}\,,≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + italic_C square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_δ italic_ε end_ARG ) end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG ,

for some C∈ℝ𝐶ℝC\in\mathbb{R}italic_C ∈ blackboard_R. Note that the choice of parameters ensures 1K≤ε21𝐾𝜀2\frac{1}{K}\leq\frac{\varepsilon}{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Setting δ=ε⁢(1−γ)4𝛿𝜀1𝛾4\delta=\frac{\varepsilon\left(1-\gamma\right)}{4}italic_δ = divide start_ARG italic_ε ( 1 - italic_γ ) end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG and

τE≥C2⁢d(1−γ)2⁢ε2⁢log⁡(Bθ⁢Bφ⁢A(1−γ)⁢δ⁢ε)subscript𝜏Esuperscript𝐶2𝑑superscript1𝛾2superscript𝜀2subscript𝐵𝜃subscript𝐵𝜑𝐴1𝛾𝛿𝜀\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\geq\frac{C^{2}d}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}% \varepsilon^{2}}\log\left(\frac{B_{\theta}B_{\varphi}A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)% \delta\varepsilon}\right)\,italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_δ italic_ε end_ARG )

this bound implies that 2K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[Δ⁢(πk)]≤4⁢ε2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝜋𝑘4𝜀\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\leq 4\varepsilondivide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ≤ 4 italic_ε. Thus, we conclude that 𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]≤5⁢ε𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜌subscript𝜋Esuperscript𝜌superscript𝜋out5𝜀\mathbb{E}\bigl{[}\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{% \mathrm{out}}}\bigr{]}\leq 5\varepsilonblackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 5 italic_ε. ∎

B.6 Proof of Lemma 4 (concentration nonlinear case)

Before presenting the proof of Theorem 2, we provide a bound on the covering number of the class 𝒬×Π𝒬𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}caligraphic_Q × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined in Equation (4). It turns out that the covering number of this class is exponential in K𝐾Kitalic_K. In the linear case, the exponential dependence in K𝐾Kitalic_K was avoided because the state-action value class is closed under addition.

Lemma 7 (Covering number of Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

It holds that the covering number of the policy class Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be bounded as

𝒩ϵ(Π𝒬,∥⋅∥1)≤𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K,\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right% )\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}\,,caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where, with a slight abuse of notation, ∥⋅∥1\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the norm defined for any π∈Π𝒬𝜋subscriptΠ𝒬\pi\in\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}italic_π ∈ roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ∥π∥1=supx∈𝒳∥π(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)∥1\left\|{\pi}\right\|_{1}=\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot% \nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}∥ italic_π ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover,

𝒩ϵ(𝒬×Π𝒬,∥⋅∥∞,1)≤𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K+1.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty,1}\right)\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(% \mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K+1}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Proof.

Let us consider two policies π𝜋\piitalic_π and π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the class Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There exist Q1,…,QK∈𝒬subscript𝑄1…subscript𝑄𝐾𝒬Q_{1},\dots,Q_{K}\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Q and Q1′,…,QK′∈𝒬superscriptsubscript𝑄1′…superscriptsubscript𝑄𝐾′𝒬Q_{1}^{\prime},\dots,Q_{K}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_Q such that for any state-action pair (x,a)∈𝒳×𝒜𝑥𝑎𝒳𝒜\left(x,a\right)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_x , italic_a ) ∈ caligraphic_X × caligraphic_A, π𝜋\piitalic_π and π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be written as

π(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=exp⁡(η⁢∑k=1KQk⁢(x,a))∑b∈𝒜exp⁡(η⁢∑k=1KQk⁢(x,b)),\pi\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)=\frac{% \exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A% }}\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}\left(x,b\right)\right)}\,,italic_π ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_b ) ) end_ARG ,

and

π′(a\nonscript|\nonscriptx)=exp⁡(η⁢∑k=1KQk′⁢(x,a))∑b∈𝒜exp⁡(η⁢∑k=1KQk′⁢(x,b)).\pi^{\prime}\left(a\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right% )=\frac{\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)\right)}{% \sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\eta\sum_{k=1}^{K}Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,b% \right)\right)}\,.italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_a | italic_x ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_b ) ) end_ARG .

Let x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X. Using ∥⋅∥1≤A∥⋅∥\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\cdot}\right\|∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG ∥ ⋅ ∥ in ℝAsuperscriptℝ𝐴\mathbb{R}^{A}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and by 1111-Lipshitzness of the softmax function (Lemma 11), it holds that

∥π(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)−π′(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)∥1\displaystyle\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript% \mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}∥ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_x ) - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤A∥π(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)−π′(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)∥\displaystyle\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}\middle|% \nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{}% \middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|≤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG ∥ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_x ) - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ∥
≤η⁢A⁢‖∑k=1K(Qk⁢(x,⋅)−Qk′⁢(x,⋅))‖absent𝜂𝐴normsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑄𝑘𝑥⋅superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘′𝑥⋅\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A}\left\|{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(Q_{k}\left(x,\cdot% \right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,\cdot\right)\right)}\right\|≤ italic_η square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG ∥ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , ⋅ ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , ⋅ ) ) ∥
≤η⁢A⁢∑k=1K‖Qk⁢(x,⋅)−Qk′⁢(x,⋅)‖absent𝜂𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾normsubscript𝑄𝑘𝑥⋅superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘′𝑥⋅\displaystyle\leq\eta\sqrt{A}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}\left(x,\cdot\right)-Q% _{k}^{\prime}\left(x,\cdot\right)}\right\|≤ italic_η square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , ⋅ ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , ⋅ ) ∥ (Triangle inequality)
≤η⁢A⁢∑k=1Ksupa∈𝒜|Qk⁢(x,a)−Qk′⁢(x,a)|absent𝜂𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsupremum𝑎𝒜subscript𝑄𝑘𝑥𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘′𝑥𝑎\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sup_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left|{Q_{k}\left(x% ,a\right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)}\right|≤ italic_η italic_A ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) | (∥⋅∥≤A∥⋅∥∞)\displaystyle(\left\|{\cdot}\right\|\leq\sqrt{A}\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty})( ∥ ⋅ ∥ ≤ square-root start_ARG italic_A end_ARG ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
≤η⁢A⁢supx∈𝒳{∑k=1Ksupa∈𝒜|Qk⁢(x,a)−Qk′⁢(x,a)|}absent𝜂𝐴subscriptsupremum𝑥𝒳superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsupremum𝑎𝒜subscript𝑄𝑘𝑥𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘′𝑥𝑎\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sup_{a\in% \mathcal{A}}\left|{Q_{k}\left(x,a\right)-Q_{k}^{\prime}\left(x,a\right)}\right% |\right\}≤ italic_η italic_A roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_a ) | }
≤η⁢A⁢∑k=1K‖Qk−Qk′‖∞absent𝜂𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptnormsubscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘′\displaystyle\leq\eta A\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}-Q_{k}^{\prime}}\right\|_{\infty}≤ italic_η italic_A ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Triangle inequality).(Triangle inequality)\displaystyle\text{(Triangle inequality)}\,.(Triangle inequality) .

In particular, this implies

maxx∈𝒳∥π(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)−π′(⋅\nonscript|\nonscriptx)∥1≤ηA∑k=1K∥Qk′−Qk∥∞.\displaystyle\max_{x\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|{\pi\left(\cdot\nonscript\mathpunct{% }\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)-\pi^{\prime}\left(\cdot\nonscript% \mathpunct{}\middle|\nonscript\mathpunct{}x\right)}\right\|_{1}\leq\eta A\sum_% {k=1}^{K}\left\|{Q_{k}^{\prime}-Q_{k}}\right\|_{\infty}\,.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_x ) - italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_η italic_A ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Thus, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-covering number for Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝒩ϵ(Π𝒬,∥⋅∥1)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is upper-bounded by the ϵK⁢η⁢Aitalic-ϵ𝐾𝜂𝐴\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG-covering number of the class 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q to the power K𝐾Kitalic_K, i.e., 𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|% _{\infty}\right)^{K}caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus,

𝒩ϵ(Π𝒬,∥⋅∥1)≤𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right% )\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The proof is concluded by noting that the covering number increases with the precision (when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ decreases), and therefore, we can write

𝒩ϵ(𝒬×Π𝒬,∥⋅∥∞,1)\displaystyle\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤𝒩ϵ/2(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)𝒩ϵ/2(Π𝒬,∥⋅∥1)\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left% \|{\cdot}\right\|_{1}\right)≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
≤𝒩ϵ/2(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon/2}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q% },\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K}≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ / 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
≤𝒩ϵK⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)K+1.\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{N}_{\frac{\epsilon}{K\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left% \|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)^{K+1}\,.≤ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

∎

Finally, the following result proves the concentration of the estimators used in Algorithm 2.

Lemma 8.

Let {πk}k∈[K]subscriptsubscript𝜋𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}_{k\in\left[K\right]}{ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the sequence of policies generated by Algorithm 2. Then, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, for any k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ], it holds that

supQ∈𝒬|ℒ^⁢(πk,Q)−ℒ⁢(πk,Q)|≤12⁢K+2(K+1)log(2𝒩(1−γ)/8⁢K(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE.\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}}\left|{\widehat{\mathcal{L}}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)-% \mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k},Q\right)}\right|\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K% +1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\left(1-\gamma\right)/8K}\left(\mathcal{Q},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2% }\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q ∈ caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | over^ start_ARG caligraphic_L end_ARG ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) - caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q ) | ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_γ ) / 8 italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .
Proof.

Note that by construction, the policy sequence {πk}k∈[K]subscriptsubscript𝜋𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\left\{\pi_{k}\right\}_{k\in\left[K\right]}{ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by Algorithm 2 belongs to the policy class Π𝒬subscriptΠ𝒬\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, invoking Lemma 5, we have that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, for any k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in\left[K\right]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ], it holds that

Δ⁢(πk)≤infϵ:ϵ>0{4⁢ϵ1−γ+2log(2𝒩ϵ(𝒬×Π𝒬,∥⋅∥∞,1)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE}.\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\leq\inf_{\epsilon:\epsilon>0}\left\{\frac{4\epsilon% }{1-\gamma}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathcal{Q}% \times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)% }{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\right\}\,.roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ : italic_ϵ > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { divide start_ARG 4 italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG } .

Therefore, choosing ϵ=1−γ8⁢Kitalic-ϵ1𝛾8𝐾\epsilon=\frac{1-\gamma}{8K}italic_ϵ = divide start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K end_ARG, we get

Δ⁢(πk)Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\displaystyle\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤12⁢K+2log(2𝒩(1−γ)/8⁢K(𝒬×Π𝒬,∥⋅∥∞,1)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\left(1-% \gamma\right)/8K}\left(\mathcal{Q}\times\Pi_{\mathcal{Q}},\left\|{\cdot}\right% \|_{\infty,1}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_γ ) / 8 italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q × roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG
≤12⁢K+2(K+1)log(2𝒩1−γ8⁢K2⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE.\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2K}+\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K+1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal% {N}_{\frac{1-\gamma}{8K^{2}\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{% \infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_K end_ARG + square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

∎

B.7 Proof of Theorem 2 (sample complexity guarantee for Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs)

We are now ready for the proof of Theorem 2, which we restate for convenience.

See 2

Proof.

Recall that by Proposition 1, we have

𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]≤1K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[ℒ⁢(πk;Qk)]+2K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[Δ⁢(πk)].𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜌subscript𝜋Esuperscript𝜌superscript𝜋out1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑄𝑘2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(% \pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)\right]+\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta% \left(\pi_{k}\right)\right]\,.blackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] .

Then, by Lemma 2, it holds that

1K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[ℒ⁢(πk;Qk)]≤log⁡(A)η⁢K+η(1−γ)2.1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝔼delimited-[]ℒsubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑄𝑘𝐴𝜂𝐾𝜂superscript1𝛾2\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{L}\left(\pi_{k};Q_{k}\right)% \right]\leq\frac{\log\left(A\right)}{\eta K}+\frac{\eta}{\left(1-\gamma\right)% ^{2}}\,.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ caligraphic_L ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_η italic_K end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

Moreover, by Lemma 8, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, it holds that

2⁢∑k=1KΔ⁢(πk)≤1+2⁢K⁢2(K+1)log(2𝒩1−γ8⁢K2⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE.\displaystyle 2\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)\leq 1+2K\sqrt{\frac{2% \left(K+1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\frac{1-\gamma}{8K^{2}\eta A}}\left(% \mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}\,.2 ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ 1 + 2 italic_K square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG .

Since 1K⁢∑k=1KΔ⁢(πk)1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Δsubscript𝜋𝑘\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta\left(\pi_{k}\right)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is bounded almost surely by 4⁢(1−γ)−14superscript1𝛾14\left(1-\gamma\right)^{-1}4 ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0italic_δ > 0

2K⁢∑k=1K𝔼⁢[Δ⁢(πk)]≤1K+2⁢2(K+1)log(2𝒩1−γ8⁢K2⁢η⁢A(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE+4⁢δ1−γ.\displaystyle\frac{2}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}\left[\Delta\left(\pi_{k}% \right)\right]\leq\frac{1}{K}+2\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K+1\right)\log\left(2% \mathcal{N}_{\frac{1-\gamma}{8K^{2}\eta A}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}% \right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{% \scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}+\frac{4\delta}{1-\gamma}\,.divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_A end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 4 italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG .

Setting η=(1−γ)⁢2⁢log⁡(A)/K𝜂1𝛾2𝐴𝐾\eta=\left(1-\gamma\right)\sqrt{2\log\left(A\right)/K}italic_η = ( 1 - italic_γ ) square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log ( italic_A ) / italic_K end_ARG, we get

𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]≤2⁢log⁡(A)(1−γ)2⁢K+1K+2⁢2(K+1)log(2𝒩ϵ′(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)/δ)(1−γ)2⁢τE+4⁢δ1−γ,\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(A\right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}K}% }+\frac{1}{K}+2\sqrt{\frac{2\left(K+1\right)\log\left(2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon^{% \prime}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)/\delta\right)% }{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}+\frac{4\delta% }{1-\gamma}\,,blackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_K + 1 ) roman_log ( 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_δ ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 4 italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG ,

where we denoted ϵ′=12⁢8⁢K3/2⁢log⁡(A)⁢Asuperscriptitalic-ϵ′128superscript𝐾32𝐴𝐴\epsilon^{\prime}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}8K^{3/2}\sqrt{\log\left(A\right)}A}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG 8 italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG italic_A end_ARG. Setting δ=(1−γ)⁢ε4𝛿1𝛾𝜀4\delta=\frac{\left(1-\gamma\right)\varepsilon}{4}italic_δ = divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG and K=2⁢log⁡A(1−γ)2⁢ε2𝐾2𝐴superscript1𝛾2superscript𝜀2K=\frac{2\log A}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}italic_K = divide start_ARG 2 roman_log italic_A end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, we further have

𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]≤ε+ε2+4⁢log⁡(A)(1−γ)4⁢ε2⁢τE⁢log⁡(2𝒩ϵ′(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)δ).\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]\leq\varepsilon+\frac{\varepsilon}{2}+4\sqrt{\frac{\log\left(A% \right)}{\left(1-\gamma\right)^{4}\varepsilon^{2}\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}}\log\left(\frac{2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon^{\prime}}\left(\mathcal{Q},% \left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)}{\delta}\right)}\,.blackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_ε + divide start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 4 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG .

Finally, setting

τE≥16⁢log⁡(A)(1−γ)4⁢ε4⁢log⁡(2𝒩ϵ′(𝒬,∥⋅∥∞)δ),\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}\geq\frac{16\log\left(A\right)}{\left(1-% \gamma\right)^{4}\varepsilon^{4}}\log\left(\frac{2\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon^{% \prime}}\left(\mathcal{Q},\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{\infty}\right)}{\delta}% \right)\,,italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG 16 roman_log ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_Q , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) ,

we guarantee that

𝔼⁢[ρπE−ρπout]=𝒪⁢(ε).𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝜌subscript𝜋Esuperscript𝜌superscript𝜋out𝒪𝜀\mathbb{E}\left[\rho^{{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}}-\rho^{\pi^{\mathrm% {out}}}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon\right)\,.blackboard_E [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = caligraphic_O ( italic_ε ) .

∎

Appendix C Technical tools

Lemma 9 (Hoeffding’s inequality).

Let X1,…,Xnsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be independent random variables such that |Xi|≤Msubscript𝑋𝑖𝑀\left|{X_{i}}\right|\leq M| italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_M for all i𝑖iitalic_i. Then, for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0,

ℙ⁢(|1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi−𝔼⁢(Xi))|>ϵ)≤2⁢e−2⁢n⁢ϵ2M2.ℙ1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑋𝑖𝔼subscript𝑋𝑖italic-ϵ2superscript𝑒2𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝑀2\mathbb{P}\left(\left|{\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\left(X_{i}-\mathbb{E}\left(X_% {i}\right)\right)}\right|>\epsilon\right)\leq 2e^{-\frac{2n\epsilon^{2}}{M^{2}% }}\,.blackboard_P ( | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) | > italic_ϵ ) ≤ 2 italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 italic_n italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Lemma 10 (Simplified version of Orabona, 2023, Theorem 6.10).

Let us consider a non-empty closed convex set V𝑉Vitalic_V, an arbitrary sequence of adaptively chosen loss vectors (ℓk)k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℓ𝑘𝐾𝑘1\left(\ell_{k}\right)^{K}_{k=1}( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ‖ℓk‖∞≤ℓmaxsubscriptnormsubscriptℓ𝑘subscriptℓ\left\|{\ell_{k}}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\ell_{\max}∥ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and let D:V×int⁢(V)→ℝ:𝐷→𝑉int𝑉ℝD:V\times\mathrm{int}\left(V\right)\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_D : italic_V × roman_int ( italic_V ) → blackboard_R be a Bregman divergence induced by a λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ-strongly convex function in the ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm. Then, for all u∈V𝑢𝑉u\in Vitalic_u ∈ italic_V, the sequence (xk)k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝐾𝑘1\left(x_{k}\right)^{K}_{k=1}( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated for any k𝑘kitalic_k as

xk+1= arg minv∈V{⟨ℓk,v⟩+1η⁢D⁢(v,xk)}subscript𝑥𝑘1subscript arg min𝑣𝑉subscriptℓ𝑘𝑣1𝜂𝐷𝑣subscript𝑥𝑘x_{k+1}=\mathop{\mbox{ arg\,min}}_{v\in V}\left\{\left\langle\ell_{k},v\right% \rangle+\frac{1}{\eta}D\left(v,x_{k}\right)\right\}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = arg min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ⟨ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v ⟩ + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG italic_D ( italic_v , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) }

for an arbitrary initial x1subscript𝑥1x_{1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

∑k=1K⟨ℓk,xk−u⟩≤D⁢(u,x1)η+η⁢K⁢ℓmax22⁢λ.subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑘1subscriptℓ𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘𝑢𝐷𝑢subscript𝑥1𝜂𝜂𝐾subscriptsuperscriptℓ22𝜆\sum^{K}_{k=1}\left\langle\ell_{k},x_{k}-u\right\rangle\leq\frac{D\left(u,x_{1% }\right)}{\eta}+\frac{\eta K\ell^{2}_{\max}}{2\lambda}\,.∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u ⟩ ≤ divide start_ARG italic_D ( italic_u , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η italic_K roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_λ end_ARG .
Lemma 11 (Gao and Pavel, 2017, Proposition 4).

For any η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0, let the softmax function be defined for any z∈ℝn𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛z\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_z ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as

softmax⁡(z)=(eη⁢zi∑j=1neη⁢zj)i∈[n].softmax𝑧subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝑧𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑗1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝑧𝑗𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\operatorname{softmax}\left(z\right)=\left(\frac{e^{\eta z_{i}}}{\sum^{n}_{j=1% }e^{\eta z_{j}}}\right)_{i\in\left[n\right]}\,.roman_softmax ( italic_z ) = ( divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Then, the softmax function is η𝜂\etaitalic_η-Lipschitz with respect to ∥⋅∥2\left\|{\cdot}\right\|_{2}∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That is, for any z,z′∈ℝn𝑧superscript𝑧′superscriptℝ𝑛z,z^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_z , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

‖softmax⁡(z)−softmax⁡(z′)‖2≤η⁢‖z−z′‖2.subscriptnormsoftmax𝑧softmaxsuperscript𝑧′2𝜂subscriptnorm𝑧superscript𝑧′2\left\|{\operatorname{softmax}\left(z\right)-\operatorname{softmax}\left(z^{% \prime}\right)}\right\|_{2}\leq\eta\left\|{z-z^{\prime}}\right\|_{2}\,.∥ roman_softmax ( italic_z ) - roman_softmax ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_η ∥ italic_z - italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Lemma 12 (Covering number of a Euclidean ball).

The covering number of the Euclidean ball of radius R𝑅Ritalic_R in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝔅⁢(R)𝔅𝑅\mathfrak{B}\left(R\right)fraktur_B ( italic_R ), is

𝒩ϵ(𝔅(R),∥⋅∥)≤(1+2⁢Rϵ)d.\mathcal{N}_{\epsilon}\left(\mathfrak{B}\left(R\right),\left\|{\cdot}\right\|% \right)\leq\left(1+\frac{2R}{\epsilon}\right)^{d}\,.caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( fraktur_B ( italic_R ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ ) ≤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 2 italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Appendix D On the guarantees of misspecified BC in linear Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDPs

It is natural to question whether existing bounds for behavioral cloning (BC) in misspecified settings [e.g., Rohatgi et al., 2025, Foster et al., 2024] offer satisfactory sample complexity guarantees for imitating an arbitrarily complex expert within a linear Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDP. This section presents a negative result, demonstrating that the approximation error incurred by BC, when restricted to a linear softmax policy class (denoted ΠlinsubscriptΠlin\Pi_{\text{lin}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), can be large even in a simple linear Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable MDP.

Consider a single-state MDP defined as follows. Let A∈ℕ∗𝐴superscriptℕA\in\mathbb{N}^{*}italic_A ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the number of actions, with the action space 𝒜=[[1,…,A]]𝒜delimited-[]1…𝐴\mathcal{A}=\left[\![1,\dots,A\right]\!]caligraphic_A = [ [ 1 , … , italic_A ] ]. For each action a∈𝒜𝑎𝒜a\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A, there is a scalar feature φ⁢(a)=−A2+a∈ℝ𝜑𝑎𝐴2𝑎ℝ\varphi\left(a\right)=-\frac{A}{2}+a\in\mathbb{R}italic_φ ( italic_a ) = - divide start_ARG italic_A end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_a ∈ blackboard_R. To ensure the MDP is linear Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizable, the true reward function is rtrue⁢(a)=ζ⁢φ⁢(a)subscript𝑟true𝑎𝜁𝜑𝑎r_{\text{true}}\left(a\right)=\zeta\varphi\left(a\right)italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = italic_ζ italic_φ ( italic_a ) for some parameter ζ∈ℝ𝜁ℝ\zeta\in\mathbb{R}italic_ζ ∈ blackboard_R unknown to the learner. We define a softmax quadratic expert policy πEsubscript𝜋E{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as

πE⁢(a)=exp⁡(φ⁢(a)2)∑b∈𝒜exp⁡(φ⁢(b)2).subscript𝜋E𝑎𝜑superscript𝑎2subscript𝑏𝒜𝜑superscript𝑏2{\pi_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}\left(a\right)=\frac{\exp\left(\varphi% \left(a\right)^{2}\right)}{\sum_{b\in\mathcal{A}}\exp\left(\varphi\left(b% \right)^{2}\right)}\,.italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = divide start_ARG roman_exp ( italic_φ ( italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_φ ( italic_b ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG .

This expert policy assigns the highest probability to extremal actions (i.e., a=1𝑎1a=1italic_a = 1 and a=A𝑎𝐴a=Aitalic_a = italic_A). In contrast, linear softmax policies π∈Πlin𝜋subscriptΠlin\pi\in\Pi_{\text{lin}}italic_π ∈ roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which are commonly used for BC in feature-based settings) are inherently designed to produce monotonic probability distributions over the action space when features are ordered (i.e., for actions a,a′∈𝒜𝑎superscript𝑎′𝒜a,a^{\prime}\in\mathcal{A}italic_a , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_A with a′>asuperscript𝑎′𝑎a^{\prime}>aitalic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_a, either π⁢(a)≤π⁢(a′)𝜋𝑎𝜋superscript𝑎′\pi\left(a\right)\leq\pi\left(a^{\prime}\right)italic_π ( italic_a ) ≤ italic_π ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or π⁢(a)≥π⁢(a′)𝜋𝑎𝜋superscript𝑎′\pi\left(a\right)\geq\pi\left(a^{\prime}\right)italic_π ( italic_a ) ≥ italic_π ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). Consequently, for A>2𝐴2A>2italic_A > 2, no policy in ΠlinsubscriptΠlin\Pi_{\text{lin}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT lin end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can achieve a small Hellinger distance to this softmax quadratic expert. We illustrate this in Figure 3, where we compare the softmax quadratic expert with two linear softmax policies. Due to the monotonicity constraint, the linear softmax policies are unable to approximate the expert policy everywhere.

It remains an open question whether behavioral cloning analyses can be refined to better leverage the underlying MDP structure in such misspecified scenarios. Specifically, for the constructed example, it would be advantageous if the misspecification error in existing bounds were characterized in terms of feature expectations (e.g., ∑a∈𝒜π⁢(a)⁢φ⁢(a)subscript𝑎𝒜𝜋𝑎𝜑𝑎\sum_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\pi\left(a\right)\varphi\left(a\right)∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ( italic_a ) italic_φ ( italic_a )) rather than state-action distributions.

Appendix E Experimental details

For the first experiment shown in Figure 1, one may wonder if the underperformance of behavioural cloning might be due to underoptimizing the empirical log-likehood. We have ruled out this possibility by going into great lengths to optimize the likelihood, and in fact the log-likelihood has approached its minimum value of zero very closely in our experiment (meaning that the probability assigned to the actions seen in the expert dataset is almost 1111). For this optimization task, we have used Adam with default parameter settings. For the experiments in Figure 2, algorithms are implemented using a shared neural network architecture consisting of 3 layers with 64 neurons per layer. This architecture matches the one used for experiments in the same environments by Garg et al. [2021]. For behavioral cloning, we employ a separate three-layer multilayer perceptron with 128 neurons per layer. Implementations of IQ-Learn and P2IL utilize their original hyperparameter configurations as reported in their respective publications. All networks are optimized using the Adam optimizer [Kingma and Ba, 2014] with a learning rate of 5×10−35superscript1035\times 10^{-3}5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and default momentum parameters (β1=0.9,β2=0.999formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽10.9subscript𝛽20.999\beta_{1}=0.9,\beta_{2}=0.999italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.9 , italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.999). The implementations are built using PyTorch [Paszke, 2019].

For algorithms with a primal-dual structure (i.e., IQ-Learn, P2IL, and SPOIL), the policy update is performed using a Soft DQN-style update [cf. Haarnoja et al., 2017] with a fixed temperature parameter. These three algorithms thus only differ in terms of their Q-value updates, and thus this experiment serves to assess the effectiveness of the novel critic loss introduced in this work.

Appendix F Future directions

Possible improvements.

The most interesting immediate question that one can ask about our result is if the 𝒪⁢(ε−4)𝒪superscript𝜀4\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-4}\right)caligraphic_O ( italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) scaling featured in our general bound is improvable under the conditions we assume. We believe that substantially different algorithmic and analytic ideas would be necessary to answer this question, but we also think that our primal-dual framework provides a good starting point towards making such improvements. Furthermore, we would be curious to investigate appropriate notions of misspecification that our algorithm can deal with. It can be easily shown that requiring Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-realizability only up to a worst-case additive error of order εapproxsubscript𝜀approx\varepsilon_{\text{approx}}italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT approx end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would incur the same additional term in the error bounds, but we believe that this assumption is too strong to warrant interest and we did not include an explicit statement. A much more interesting question is if this approximation guarantee would only be required to hold locally in the state-action pairs visited by the expert, or only for specific policies (most ideally only the expert policy). Given the numerous negative results in RL theory about such weaker function approximators, we are not optimistic that these latter improvements are possible, but nevertheless (and once again), we feel that our analytic framework can provide suitable tools for analyzing such questions.

Learning from features only.

In the case of linear function approximation, the current approach critically relies on observing the expert state-action pairs to compute the vectors {g^k}k=1Ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑘𝐾𝑘1\left\{\widehat{g}_{k}\right\}^{K}_{k=1}{ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It would be interesting to check if an alternative algorithm can achieve the same guarantees by only observing the feature vectors instead. In other words, the design of an algorithm taking as input a dataset {φ⁢(XEi,AEi)}i=1τEsubscriptsuperscript𝜑superscriptsubscript𝑋E𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐴E𝑖subscript𝜏E𝑖1\left\{\varphi\left(X_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}^{i},A_{\scriptscriptstyle% \textup{E}}^{i}\right)\right\}^{\tau_{\scriptscriptstyle\textup{E}}}_{i=1}{ italic_φ ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an interesting open problem.

New efficient algorithms that learn state-action value functions from expert data.

Despite having proven successful in practice [Garg et al., 2021], the idea of learning a state-action value function from expert data without passing through a learned reward function has not been used to develop theoretically grounded algorithms. Our work is the first example of an algorithm enjoying theoretical guarantees applying this principle. We expect this principle to find other applications in imitation learning theory, for example on the open problem of learning to imitate an expert from state-only trajectory given trajectory access to a linear-Qπsuperscript𝑄𝜋Q^{\pi}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT realizable MDP.

Generated on Mon May 26 13:10:39 2025 by LaTeXML
